facts.text: The respondents are owners of the building at No. 41 Purani Mandi, Ajmer.

anchor.surface_text: The building situate at No. 41 Purani Mandi, Ajmer, companysists of a large number of rooms, and the respondents are its owners.

facts.text: Appellant's father took the building on lease on October 13, 1935 for one year at Rs. 50 per month.

anchor.surface_text: On October 13, 1935, the said building was taken on lease by the appellants father for a period of one year on a rent of Rs. 50/- per month.

facts.text: Respondents gave lease of the building to appellant on July 10, 1950 for one year at Rs. 65 per month.

anchor.surface_text: On July 10, 1950, the respondents gave a lease of the said building in favour of the appellant for a period of one year on a rent of Rs. 65/- per month.

facts.text: Fresh lease executed in favour of appellant on August 8, 1952 at Rs. 70 per month, tenancy to commence from August 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On August 8, 1952, a fresh lease was executed in favour of the appellant on an enhanced rent of Rs. 70/- per month. Under the said lease the tenancy was to companymence from August 1, 1952.

facts.text: Lease of August 8, 1952 was for a period of one year.

anchor.surface_text: Under the said lease the tenancy was to companymence from August 1, 1952. On June 27, 1954, the respondents issued a numberice to the appellant,

facts.text: On June 27, 1954, respondents issued notice to appellant to vacate by midnight of July 31, 1954/August 1, 1954, alleging arrears of rent and subletting.

anchor.surface_text: On June 27, 1954, the respondents issued a numberice to the appellant, through their Advocates, calling upon him to vacate the premises by midnight of July 31, 1954/August 1, 1954. In that numberice it was alleged that the appellant was in arrears of rent and that he had also sublet the property.

facts.text: In reply notice, appellant promised to pay arrears of rent as early as possible and stated he had been subletting portions of premises except portion under his occupation.

anchor.surface_text: In the reply numberice the appellant promised to pay the arrears of rent as early as possible, but stated that he had all along been subletting portions of the premises to others, except the portion under his occupation.

facts.text: Appellant did not comply with the terms of the notice.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellant did number companyply with the terms of the numberice, the respondents filed on August 2, 1954, Civil Suit No. 762 of 1954

facts.text: On August 2, 1954, respondents filed Civil Suit No. 762 of 1954 in Court of Subordinate Judge, First Class, Ajmer against appellant for eviction, recovery of arrears and other reliefs.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents filed on August 2, 1954, Civil Suit No. 762 of 1954 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Ajmer, against the appellant for eviction, for recovery of arrears of rent and for other reliefs.

facts.text: The plaint was later amended.

anchor.surface_text: The plaint was later on amended. The appellant companytested the suit on various grounds

facts.text: Appellant contested the suit on various grounds including that it was not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytested the suit on various grounds and particularly on the ground that it was number maintainable. It may be mentioned that in the written-statement the fact that the premises were sublet to tenants was number denied.

facts.text: In written statement, appellant did not deny subletting the premises to tenants.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that in the written-statement the fact that the premises were sublet to tenants was number denied. The learned Subordinate Judge decreed the suit, holding that the numberice was valid

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, First Class, Ajmer decreed the suit holding notice valid and appellant liable to eviction under s.13(1)(b) of Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952 for subletting without landlord's consent in writing.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge decreed the suit, holding that the numberice was valid and that the appellant was liable to be evicted under s. 13 1  b  of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952,  XXXVIII of 1952 , hereinafter called the Act, as he had sublet portions of the premises without the companysent in writing of the landlord.

facts.text: On appeal, Senior Civil Judge, Ajmer allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Senior Civil Judge, Ajmer, allowed the appeal. He held that the numberice issued to the appellant was short by 24 hours

facts.text: Senior Civil Judge held notice was short by 24 hours.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the numberice issued to the appellant was short by 24 hours and that he had numberright to sublet the premises without the written companysent of the landlord,

facts.text: Senior Civil Judge held appellant had no right to sublet without written consent though there were sub-tenants when appellant took the lease.

anchor.surface_text: and that he had numberright to sublet the premises without the written companysent of the landlord, though there where sub-tenants in the premises when the appellant took the lease.

facts.text: High Court allowed the second appeal and restored decree of trial court.

anchor.surface_text: On second appeal, the High Court allowed the appeal and restored the decree of the trial companyrt.

facts.text: High Court held notice complied with s.106 of Transfer of Property Act or not necessary as tenancy expired by efflux of time.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the numberice companyplied with the provisions of s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, and that, in any event, as the tenancy expired by mere efflux of time, numbernotice was necessary.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Subba Rao, J. This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan at Jodhpur setting aside those of the Senior Civil Judge, Ajmer, and restoring those of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Ajmer, decreeing the suit for eviction from the suit premises filed by the respondents against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant sublet portions of premises without consent in writing of landlord after commencement of 1952 Act.

anchor.surface_text: Here, admittedly after the lease deed of 1952 the appellant has sublet some of the rooms of the building to others without obtaining the written companysent of the landlord.

facts.text: New sub-tenants were inducted by appellant after earlier sub-tenancies terminated, not holding under earlier sub-tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that there were sub-tenants in the said portions companyld number companyceivably be of any help to the appellant, because the new sub-tenants were number holding under the earlier sub-tenants, but were inducted by the appellant, after the earlier sub-tenancies were terminated.

facts.text: Lease deed dated August 8, 1952 filed with plaint, terms show lease for one year.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents alleged in the plaint that the appellant was their tenant under the lease deed dated August 8, 1952, and they filed, along with the plaint the said lease deed, the terms whereof clearly show that the term of the was for one year.

facts.text: Appellant admitted facts of lease deed dated August 8, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant admitted those facts. It is, therefore, manifest that the appellant never denied that the term of the lease was number for one year.

anchor.surface_text: for we are satisfied that the term of the tenancy had expired by efflux of time and, therefore, no question of statutory notice would arise. But the learned counsel contends that this point

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease deed dated August 8, 1952 explicitly for one year commencing August 1, 1952; admitted by appellant; fixed term ends automatically without s.106 TPA notice

holdings.text: The efflux of time point was raised in the plaint via the lease deed filed and admitted, depending solely on construction of the lease deed

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, justified in considering the point, because the validity of the notice depended upon the term of the tenancy and also because the question of the term of the tenancy depended solely on the construction of the lease deed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaint alleged tenancy under 1952 lease deed filed therewith showing one-year term; appellant admitted facts; pure question of law on document

holdings.text: The lease was for a period of one year and it was not a monthly tenancy

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, manifest that the appellant never denied that the term of the lease was not for one year. The High Court was, therefore, justified in considering the point... The document says that the house had been taken on rent for one year

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease deed terms: 'house had been taken on rent for one year'; clause on arrears allows ejectment before expiry but confirms fixed one-year term

holdings.text: The appellant had sublet the premises within the meaning of s.13(1)(b)(i) of the Act by inducting new sub-tenants after the 1952 lease without written consent

anchor.surface_text: Here, admittedly after the lease deed of 1952 the appellant has sublet some of the rooms of the building to others without obtaining the written consent of the landlord. The fact that there were sub-tenants in the said portions could not conceivably be of any help to the appellant, because the new sub-tenants were not holding under the earlier sub-tenants, but were inducted by the appellant, after the earlier sub-tenancies were terminated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear words of s.13(1)(b)(i) apply to any subletting post-Act commencement without consent; new inductions by tenant after prior terminations constitute subletting, not mere substitution

holdings.text: The appellant, having sub-let part of the premises without the consent of the landlord in writing, cannot invoke the protection given to him under s.13 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, having sub-let part of the premises without the consent of the landlord in writing, cannot invoke the protection given to him under s. 13 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.13(1)(b)(i) eviction ground overrides tenant protections

holdings.text: The High Court was right in setting aside the decree of the Civil Judge as it was not according to law

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the High Court was certainly right in setting aside the decree of the Civil Judge, for the Civil Judge refused to pass an order of eviction on a wrong legal basis that the appellant was a monthly tenant, ignoring the express term in the lease deed itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Civil Judge erred on tenancy term and notice; ignored lease deed; s.35(1) permits correction

precedents.citation: Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdhari Lal Chowdhury 1962 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 933

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed by the learned counsel on a decision of this Court in Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdhari Lal Chowdhury 1962 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 933, in support of the contention that the jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 35 of the Act is very limited and does not warrant the High Courts interference in the circumstances of this case. The main question in that decision was whether the plaintiff consented to the subletting of parts of the demised premises and if so, when and to what effect ?

precedents.case_name: Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdhari Lal Chowdhury
precedents.cited_proposition: scope and ambit of High Court jurisdiction under s. 35 of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952, which is wider than under s. 115 CPC but not appellate jurisdiction; 'according to law' means no miscarriage of justice due to mistake of law
precedents.cited_holding: The phrase according to law refers to the decision as a whole, and is not to be equated to errors of law or of fact simpliciter. It refers to the overall decision, which must be according to law which it would not be, if there is a miscarriage of justice due to a mistake of law.

precedents.citation: Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj  1938  40 Bom. L.R. 125

anchor.surface_text: Then the learned Judge quoted in extenso the observations of Beaumont, C.J.  as he then was  in Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj  1938  40 Bom. L.R. 125 and recorded his full concurrence with those observations. By those observations the learned Chief Justice gave certain illustrations and made it clear that they were not exhaustive and concluded thus But, in my opinion, the Court ought not to interfere merely because it thinks that possibly the Judge who heard the case may have arrived at a conclusion which the High Court would not have arrived at.

precedents.case_name: Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj
precedents.cited_proposition: scope of revisional jurisdiction under similar provision; court ought not interfere merely because it would have arrived at different conclusion

anchor.surface_text: Here, admittedly after the lease deed of 1952 the appellant has sublet some of the rooms of the building to others without obtaining the written consent of the landlord. The fact that there were sub-tenants in the said portions could not conceivably be of any help to the appellant, because the new sub-tenants were not holding under the earlier sub-tenants, but were inducted by the appellant, after the earlier sub-tenancies were terminated.

Here, admittedly after the lease deed of 1952 the appellant has sublet some of the rooms of the building to others without obtaining the written consent of the landlord. The fact that there were sub-tenants in the said portions could not conceivably be of any help to the appellant, because the new sub-tenants were not holding under the earlier sub-tenants, but were inducted by the appellant, after the earlier sub-tenancies were terminated.
The appellant, having sub-let part of the premises without the consent of the landlord in writing, cannot invoke the protection given to him under s. 13 of the Act.

In this view, the High Court was certainly right in setting aside the decree of the Civil Judge, for the Civil Judge refused to pass an order of eviction on a wrong legal basis that the appellant was a monthly tenant, ignoring the express term in the lease deed itself.
